abstract.text: An abstract class representing a dimensional unit of measure.

inlineContent.text: The Foundation framework provides concrete subclasses for many of the most common types of physical units.
Unit of measure for planar angle and rotation
Unit of measure for concentration of mass
Unit of measure for duration of time
Unit of measure for electric charge
Unit of measure for electric current
Unit of measure for electric potential difference
Unit of measure for electric resistance
Unit of measure for fuel efficiency
Unit of measure for quantities of information
, which represents the unit in terms of the dimension’s
as its base unit. The system defines the predefined
, which corresponds to the conversion ratio of miles to meters (1 mi = 1609.34 m); the system defines the predefined
class to represent specific quantities of a particular unit.

In addition to the Apple-provided units, you can define custom units. You can initialize custom units from a symbol and converter of an existing type or implemented as a class method of an existing type for additional convenience. You can also define your own
subclass to represent an entirely new unit dimension.

content.text: Initializing a Custom Unit with a Specified Symbol and Definition

inlineContent.text: The simplest way to define a custom unit is to create a new instance of an existing
is a nonstandard unit of length (1 smoot = 1.70180 m). You can create a new instance of
Alternatively, if you use a custom unit extensively throughout an app, consider extending the corresponding
subclass and adding a static variable.
For example, a measurement of speed can be furlongs per fortnight (1 fur/ftn = 201.168 m / 1,209,600 s). If an app makes frequent use of this unit, you can extend
static variable for convenient access as follows:

code: static let furlongPerFortnight = UnitSpeed(symbol: "fur/ftn", converter: UnitConverterLinear(coefficient: 201.168 / 1209600.0))

inlineContent.text: You can create a new subclass of
to describe a new unit dimension.

For example, the Foundation framework doesn’t define any units for radioactivity. Radioactivity is the process by which the nucleus of an atom emits radiation. The SI unit of measure for radioactivity is the becquerel (Bq), which is the quantity of radioactive material in which one nucleus decays per second (1 Bq = 1 s
). Radioactivity is also commonly described in terms of curies (Ci), a unit defined relative to the decay of one gram of the radium-226 isotope (1 Ci = 3.7 × 10

for subclassing. Although the subclasses listed in

are suitable for most purposes, you may want to define a custom unit type. For instance, you may need a custom unit type to represent a derived unit, such as magnetic flux (measured as the product of electric potential difference and time).
All subclasses must fully implement the
method designating the base unit, relative to which you define any additional units.
You must also implement a class method named for the base unit itself, to use interchangeably. For example, the

abstract.text: An abstract class representing a dimensional unit of measure.
The unit converter that represents the unit in terms of the dimension’s base unit.
Initializes a dimensional unit with the symbol and unit converter you specify.
A numeric quantity labeled with a unit of measure, with support for unit conversion and unit-aware calculations.
An abstract class representing a unit of measure.
